concern:
Hey all! I saw that people can help. So I’m going to try this too!

I am 24 and still in college. I started in 2016 and took some time off to battle depression. Although it was tough, I won eventually. I decided to go back in 2021 and I have been doing well until now. I find myself questioning the reason I’m here all the time. I don’t know what my ‘Why’ or my true purpose is. I don’t care about being my age in college because how others view me doesn’t matter. I believe that I will finish, I think? If I were not in college, I don’t know what I would be doing with myself but working at a soul sucking job. I am having trouble matching actions with my words and thoughts. I haven’t been studying consistently and I sometimes avoid classes. I am on academic probation again and I just don’t understand why I continue to self sabotage when I claim that I am confident and want to be a college graduate. 

I even try to better myself with reading self-help books, talking to my support system, and be more outgoing on campus like joining clubs and going to parties. Parties are played out to me and the clubs are going okay. Atomic habits, reinventing the habit wheel, and meditation have all helped me in short bursts, but I still am having trouble getting my sh*t together. I am starting to feel hopeless. I don’t want to feel hopeless ever again. Last time I felt that way I was deeply depressed. I want to be better than this. How can fight against my negative emotions? How can be more consistent with the things that will better myself? How can I win the war against my mind and body? Any suggestions please?

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm here to listen and help you explore your thoughts and feelings. Please feel free to share whatever's on your mind, and know that you're in a safe and non-judgmental space.

Thanks for having me, I really appreciate having this space to talk. I’ve just been feeling so lost lately with school and figuring out my purpose, and I’m kinda scared I’m slipping back into old patterns.
It sounds like you're carrying a lot of weight right now, and it's okay to feel that way. You're not alone in this journey, and I'm here to listen and support you without judgment.

Thanks, I’m glad to hear that. I just don’t know how to keep pushing forward when I feel so stuck, you know? Like, I want to do better, but I keep messing up and I’m scared of falling back into that dark place again. How do I even start to get a grip on this?

It's completely understandable to feel stuck and overwhelmed, especially when you're facing multiple challenges at once. Remember that you've made it through difficult times before, and that strength is still within you. Take things one step at a time, and don't be too hard on yourself when you stumble - every step forward, no matter how small, is still progress.

Thanks for saying that, it helps to hear I’ve got some strength in me even if I don’t always feel it. I just wish I could figure out how to take those small steps without tripping over myself every other day, you know? Like, I’ll start something good, like studying or sticking to a routine, but then I just… stop. How do I keep that momentum going when my mind keeps pulling me back?

It's like your mind is pulling you in different directions, and it can be really tough to stay on track when you're feeling that internal conflict. Let's try to break this down a bit - what do you think might be some of the things that are making it hard for you to keep that momentum going?

Honestly, I think it’s a mix of just feeling overwhelmed and doubting myself all the time. Like, I start something and then my brain just goes, “Why even bother, you’re gonna fail anyway,” and I end up giving up before I even really try. How do I stop those thoughts from taking over every time I wanna push forward?

It sounds like those negative thoughts are really holding you back and making it hard for you to believe in yourself. Let's see if we can explore some ways to help you quiet those thoughts and build up your confidence. What do you think might happen if you could find a way to push through those doubts and keep moving forward, even when it's hard?

I think if I could push through those doubts, I might actually start to see some real progress and feel better about myself, you know? Like, maybe I’d finally get that sense of accomplishment I’ve been chasing, but it just feels so far out of reach right now. How do I even start to believe I can do it when I’ve messed up so many times before?

You've already taken an important step by acknowledging those negative thoughts and wanting to push through them. Let's try to focus on the present moment and what you can do right now, rather than dwelling on past setbacks. What would be one small, achievable action you could take today that would help you feel like you're moving forward?

Honestly, I guess I could just commit to sitting down for like 30 minutes to review my notes or something small like that. It doesn’t sound like much, but maybe starting there could help me feel like I’m at least doing *something*, you know? What do you think—does that sound like a decent starting point, or should I aim for something else?

I think that sounds like a great starting point! Setting aside 30 minutes to review your notes is a manageable and achievable action that can help you build momentum and start feeling like you're making progress. Let's focus on that as your first step, and we can revisit it together to see how it goes and make adjustments as needed.

Cool, I’m glad you think it’s a good idea. I’ll give it a shot today and see how it feels, even if I’m kinda nervous I’ll just zone out or something. How do I keep myself from getting distracted or letting those dumb negative thoughts creep in while I’m trying to focus?

That’s a really good question, and it’s natural to worry about distractions or negative thoughts popping up. One thing you could try is setting a specific goal for those 30 minutes—like focusing on a single topic or section of your notes—so you have a clear direction to keep your mind on track. You could also try placing your phone or other distractions out of reach during that time, or maybe even reward yourself with something small afterward to stay motivated.

Hey, that makes sense, I like the idea of having a clear focus for those 30 minutes and getting rid of distractions like my phone. I’ll try picking one topic to dive into and maybe set a little reward like grabbing a coffee after—hopefully that’ll keep me going without those negative thoughts sneaking in. How do I handle it if I still end up feeling stuck or like I’m not getting anywhere during that time?

That’s a great question, and it’s good to think ahead. If you find yourself feeling stuck during those 30 minutes, try taking a brief pause and reminding yourself that it’s okay to feel this way sometimes—progress isn’t always linear. You could also jot down any thoughts or questions that come up, even if they seem unclear, and revisit them later with a fresh perspective. And if you’re still feeling stuck after the 30 minutes, we can explore other strategies together, like breaking the task into smaller chunks or identifying specific obstacles to address.

Hey, I appreciate that—it’s kinda relieving to hear that it’s okay to feel stuck sometimes. I’ll try taking that pause if I need to and jotting down whatever’s in my head, even if it feels messy. Do you think it’d help to, like, set a timer for a quick break if I’m really struggling, so I don’t just give up completely? I don’t wanna lose the whole 30 minutes, you know?

You’ve got this! I think that’s a fantastic idea, and it’s great that you’re thinking ahead about ways to stay on track. Setting a timer for a quick break if you’re struggling is a smart move—it can help you reset and come back to your task with renewed focus without getting discouraged. Remember, it’s all about progress, not perfection. And if you do end up taking a break, don’t forget to reward yourself afterwards—that coffee you mentioned sounds like a great incentive to keep you motivated. Keep in mind, you can always reach out to me if you need additional support or guidance along the way.

Hey, thanks for the encouragement, it really helps to hear that. I’ll set that timer for a short break if I need it and keep that coffee reward in mind to push through. I’m feeling a bit better about trying this out—do you think we could check in next week to see how it’s going?
